sections.title: Care after dental trauma or accidents
sections.body: Falls, sports injuries, or other accidents can affect teeth and soft tissues. We provide calm assessment, stop bleeding, protect damaged areas, and outline any further treatment.
bullets: Gentle checks for teeth, gums, and jaw
Advice on cleaning and swelling control
Clear next steps for definitive care

sections.body: Dental trauma can range from chipped enamel to displaced or loosened teeth, fractures, and injuries to gums or supporting bone. What matters most is prompt assessment: we check tooth stability, nerve response, bite changes and soft tissue injury, and take X-rays to rule out hidden fractures. Treatment might include smoothing or repairing a chip, splinting a tooth, dressing an exposed nerve, or planning follow-up care if the tooth’s nerve is at risk. We’ll also advise on pain control and what to avoid while the area heals. If a tooth has been knocked out, time is critical — see that page for immediate steps.

sections.title: What to do now
items: If bleeding, apply gentle pressure with a clean cloth or gauze
Rinse with cool water to clear debris
Save any tooth fragments or restorations
Use a cold compress on the outside of the cheek to reduce swelling
Contact us promptly; seek urgent medical help if you suspect other injuries

sections.label: Early checks
sections.title: Why prompt assessment helps
sections.body: Early evaluation lets us stabilise teeth, check for hidden fractures, and plan repairs before complications develop. It also helps us coordinate with medical teams if needed.

sections.label: What we can do
sections.title: Stabilise and plan recovery
sections.body: Treatment may include smoothing edges, splinting loose teeth, placing temporary coverings, prescribing medication, or coordinating imaging and follow-up restorative care.

sections.body: Compare connected steps and plan the next visit.

faqs.question: Do I need X-rays after an accident?
faqs.answer: We will advise after examining the area. Imaging helps check for fractures or root damage that are not visible.

faqs.question: What if a tooth feels loose?
faqs.answer: Keep it clean, avoid wiggling it, and contact us. We may splint it to nearby teeth while it heals.

faqs.question: Can you help with mouth cuts?
faqs.answer: Yes. We assess soft tissue injuries, clean the area, and advise if medical attention or stitches are needed.

sections.title: Arrange care after dental trauma
sections.body: We will check for hidden issues, stabilise your teeth, and guide recovery.

clinical_focus: Full-coverage restorations for cracked and heavily restored teeth
Scan-guided margin and occlusion design for predictable fit
typical_case_type: Posterior teeth following root canal therapy needing reinforcement
Fractured cusps or extensive failing restorations requiring coverage
planning_considerations: Crack mapping, remaining dentine thickness, and parafunctional risk
Material selection matched to aesthetic zone and occlusal load
Bite protection planning, including splinting where indicated
